metadata.song_track: Are You Gonna Be My Girl

transcript.content: Jet - Are You Gonna Be My Girl

Jet - Are You Gonna Be My Girl on XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Stephen Merchant, over there... little roundy bald head of Karl Pilkington. Good news and bad news. Good news is, boys are back in town. We're here for two hours.
Hello.
Bad news is we have no monkey news, um, gay fellow news, or little Chinese fellow news.
Really?
We're going to try and, you know, leave that for a week and maybe come back to it. Because it was getting...
Why do I get the feeling that within 20 minutes we'll be talking about little gay Chinese monkeys.
Ricky laughs
Karl, think of that.
We have got monkey news.
Have we?
Have we?
Oh yeah.
So we've already broken that promise!
Oh, okay, I thought we were gonna try and, sort of, talk about something else. I've just done the Jonathan Ross show,and they don't talk about the same things every week. It's weird.
Mmm.
It is weird.
Mmm.
Or as Karl says, 'weird, innit?'
Yeah.
So, um, gave this show about five plugs.
Nice one.
Yeah. So, uh, I think we'll get upward of 800 people listening.
(laughing) Oh, double...
For the first two minutes.
Yeah, yeah.
And then turning back.
They're already switching over now.
I'd have thought so, yeah.

I spoke to my friend yesterday, he's a little bit of an odd fellow, and he said that he, for his own amusement, he had an iPod in his car, and he bought a little sort of transmitter, and he could transmit the music from his iPod, to sort of - just beam it, kind of, as he was driving along to, sort of, passing cars.
What do you mean?
It's weird,
Make their radio play it?
Well, if they had it in the right frequency, yeah? Um, I mean, pointless, completely pointless - but not dissimilar to this show, I imagine, in terms of the number of listeners.
Yeah, but I was gonna say, what's the chances of people having this frequency on?
Absolutely pointless.
So it's probably about the same, yeah.

Do you know what it reminds me of? When I was young, I wanted to get into radio, I was excited about radio, and I was sort of in my - I dunno, I was 11 or 12. My friend and I, we got a little mixing deck, and we used to host our own radio show.
Brilliant.
Uh, from his bedroom. We didn't have a transmitter, so we'd put some speakers in his front garden, in some bushes, and sort of broadcast it to people who were walking by.
Again, probably over the week, more listeners than this show.
Almost certainly.
That... yeah.

I love the idea, we - it never happened - but I also was hoping that some, maybe some girls would just come by and just, like, sit and listen. "These guys are great. I dunno where these sounds are coming from, it seems to be that bush, but..."
Or Noel Edmonds coming along, going "Who are these guys? Can you get them on the show?"
"Can they stand in for me when I go on holiday?"
Yeah.
I did, uh... did I tell you I did sort of pirate radio?
No, go on.
Did, uh, got into all...
(Interrupting) Yeah, normal radio, but he had an eye patch on. Go on.
Uh, Dad was in hospital, right? And, uh, he was having some operation done, right? And, uh, went to see him, and didn't have that much to say to him, right? So I was sat...
He's only your dad.
I was sat there - well, it's awkward though, innit? When someone's ill.
Yeah.
Sure.
And you don't know what to say...
(Interrupting) Boring, innit? Boring!
So I was flicking around on that little radio thing they have.
Yeah.
And I heard, like, they had a radio station in the hospital, so I said "Ah, I'm gonna go and join this." So I wandered off to go and find it.
Yeah.
Uh, sort of joined that. Did a little show on there. So I thought I can, I can, sort of get out to the masses here.
Yeah.

Me mate made a little transmitter. Did a little pirate radio show from the uh... got kicked out, because they found out, and apparently I put the station at risk, because all the stuff could've been taken off us.
But, from little acorn, 16 years later, he's on a show with less listeners.
(Laughing) Yes.
Brilliant.

Can you imagine if you're, you've gone into hospital. You're already pretty depressed, there's the fear of these bugs - super bugs in the hospital, maybe you've got some quite serious illness, you know, you don't know if you're gonna make it... his voice is what you hear to cheer you up.
(Imitating Karl) "Alright? Weird, innit? Saw a program about a parasite the other night. Yeah."
Apparently they- they get in through your eye and eat their way out through your genitals. Anyway, heres Radio Head.
You think you've got it bad.
Yeah, exactly play a record Karl.
Bit of Stone Roses yeah?
Oh, Fool's Gold. Classic!
Stone Roses - Fool's Gold
Stone Roses, Fool's Gold XFM 104.9... brilliant.
Can't help but notice you've ah, brought some sandwiches in Rick
Mm
Wha-what's it in there?
Cheese and onion.
Cheese and onion?
Yeah.
Because I've never se- never ever seen you make sandwiches before. I've seen you take a loaf, a piece of bread out of a loaf...
Yeah
...and sort of fold it in half crumbs everywhere...
Well Jane made that for me because I was in a bit of a hurry
I didn't think for a minute that you made it yourself
Why cause it looks neat?
Well, it's the wrapped in the tin foil... The- a knife has been used.
Ricky Laughs
As opposed to chewing round the baguette?
Yeah exactly
Yeah, breaking it in half...
Yeah yeah yeah
A la Albert Steptoe
Yeah
Yeah Brilliant, yeah
Yeah, nice?
It's great, but the onions are strong.
Oh are they?
Making my eyes water?
Yeah
If I come breathe on you...
Yeah
...It'd cure any sort of skin disease you might have.
Steve laughs
Skin disease. We watch that um, Karl, you know, that- Karl was raving about that thing about parasites? About worms coming out your brain that? and I watched it-
What is this? is this is a TV show?
Yeah called Body Snatchers.
Right
And it was pretty fascinating
Mmhmm
And ah, I mean, amazingly shot as well. I mean it's got to win an award for photography.
Yeah

And there was ah one bit, that um this little girl had been bitten by a mosquito and it had laid their eggs, and went to the doctor, she a lump on her neck like a boil, and ah, they pulled it out and it was like... like a bullet this maggot.
Oh!

And they put it down, and it was wriggling in her blood, Right? But the hole left was sort of aesthetically pleasing. You know li- that feeling you get like I once had an ingrown hair and I quite liked it when I pulled it out and it's a perfect little hole. and I thought "i wouldn't mind having those as long as they sort of like healed over and-"
What are you talking about?
I don't know it's weird innit?
But why would you want to hold in your body like-
No It's got pulling something out, sort of like putting something out your body, It's sort of cleansing, isn't it?
I don't know what you're talking about
No, but it's sort of like, i dont know-
Ricky Laughs
This is it, you watch one program recommended to you by Karl, you've turned into Karl.
Ricky Laughs
You want a hole in your body?!
No! It was- It was like, you know like squeezing a really good sort of like, spot- I mean, I haven't squeezed spots for ages- and I'd never had spots, but maybe that's it. I didn't have spots.
Right.
And I always thought "that'd be nice squeezing a spot."
I don't know what you're talking about-
I don't know, I don't know what I'm talking-
Why would these things be pleasurable? Why would a ha- an ingrowing hair? Thats great fun?
Yeah it was good. That was good, cause i-i got it, it was like a little lump and i pulled it, and then it pulled out and it was like- it left a little...
I know what you mean. Cause i get thick hairs and ah...
Yeah
Like, really-
Oh and when they come out it's like a bit of wax?!
Yeah
Like a- like putting out a little candle?
And that's-
I love that!
What?!
I- Yeah
When- because I've got no- not much hair on my head...
No
Right, it sort of grows thicker on my face.
No, not true
Steve laughs
Sure, but go on.
Yeah
No but it does.
Not true baby, go on.
So...
No evidence for that just made it up.
Steve laughs
So it grows sort of thicker on my neck and that...
No
And now and again I'll see like, something that's like a twig, right?
Yeah!
It's really thick.

Yeah, yeah you feel it, and if you think "oh I'm gonna have that" and then you work at it, and then when you get hold of it, it's brilliant, It's like pulling out a- it's fantastic. And it's waxy and build-up, and it pulls it out and it's stretchy. Just getting it leaves a hole.
I've just realized why we talk about Chinese people, monkeys, and gay's every week.
Ricky snickers
Why?
Because this is the sort of replacement.
Ricky Laughs
This is what we've got if we're not talking about them.
But it was great as well. And um, there's this parasite, right, that lives in this fish, right.
Mm.
And what it does, it changes the fish's behavior. Because to breathe it has to get its body temperature up so it has to get into a bird, right.
Sorry what needs to get into a bird? The fish?
The parasite. To complete its life cycle...
The parasite needs to get into a bird.
Yeah. So it changes the behaviour of the stickleback, and it makes the stickleback sort of suicidal. So the stickleback doesn't flee when it sees a heron,
It gets caught.
Right.
Because this stickleback has changed its behavior. I was— Karl didn't quite understand this.
I still don't really get it. I watched it and you see like the fat fish  an' that and you go ohh, it's not well. But I don't understand...

Well all it does is, it has to get into a bird because it has to— to breed, to lay its eggs, it has to have a raise of body temperature so it has to— the fish is cold-blooded. So it has to get into a bird which is warm-blooded. There's lots of things— certain things, at that level...
Yeah but why, why is it doing that?
Because it needs the temperature.

It needs the heat energy for its reaction. Just like for example, that's why your balls are on the outside, because the cells have to be a certain temperature to survive. I think— I don't know if it's the sperm or sertoli cells but they have to be a couple of degrees below body temperature. Otherwise, they'd be in a nice cage and we wouldn't get kicked in the nads.
What do you mean?
That's why your testicles are on the outside your body, they have to be a couple of degrees below body temperature.
Yeah, but it's not— that isn't why they're there. You see this is like the chat we had last week about the giraffe havin' a long neck.
What d'you mean?
They're there because that's where they happen to be. They didn't go "right..."
But that's what evolution is. It's a selection process. It's not a will. The balls didn't say "look, I'm too hot, let's get us outside, let's get outside of here."
All right, hang on a minute then.
What?
So a little a little man monkey, right?
Theirs are in the same place as ours.
Yeah.
But, they're walking around naked so it could be anywhere. They could be, like, on the back.
No, they call it...
It doesn't matter where they are.
Well they could be on the back, yeah.
So why aren't they?
This is a completely different... Steve!
Steve chuckles
That's...
You started it! I wash my hands of the whole affair.
And we're not only back to balls but we're back to monkey balls.
Yes!
In one thing, from— about parasites, we're back to monkey ball news.
Yeah.
How did we get back to chimp testicle news?
All right then, so this thing, this worms and a fish.
Yeah. It's— yeah it's like a little platyhelminthe. I think it's some sort of...
But what I mean is why are they about?
What do you mean?
Why?
They evolved.
But why haven't they died out?
Because they're very successful.
Yeah...
What d'you mean "yeah"? What d'you mean "yeah"? What— tell me the brain event that made you say "yeah", in that one second gap.
Cause in a way I don't get it and I— if I think about it too much it hurts a bit.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Play a record!
They've just been around for years, Karl, like Cliff Richard or something like that, you know they just...
Feeder - Forget About Tomorrow
"Forget About Tomorrow" by Feeder on Xfm 104.9. Karl is in some pain now isn't he?

What angers me is the fact that the listeners, at least they get a record. They get three minutes where they can just relax, they don't have to listen to this drivel. I've gotta sit here for another three minutes while you try to explain to this idiot...
Ricky laughs
...why we have parasites and why we have fish and why, you know... it's just interminable.

Karl's question is, "what's the point of a parasite?" I was saying well they evolved alongside everything else and it's part of the ecosystem. He's going "but why is a parasite in a fish, in a heron, back in a fish?" And I said what's the point in anything, right, apart from the balance of the ecosystem that survives at any time. And then Steve went "Karl, you should have done this when you were in sixth form"...
Yeah.
Questioning the point of life, and...
Yeah, you should have had these existential questions, you know, when you were younger.
Did you ever used to lie awake at night thinking where did the universe end?
No.
I did that when I was about six
Or seven for about a year. When I— when someone said it was...
He was lying awake at night thinking "where does Manchester end?"
Ricky laughs
"I assume it goes on forever!"
They've made a map, haven't they? For the universe.
Yep.
Right.
Well, yeah. As far as they can, yeah.
Big, is it?
It's massive.
Yeah.
But if you're that lost, d'you know what I mean, forget the map...
Ricky cackles and claps
The map's not going to help you. Sure.
If you get lost forget it! "Look, we're never going
To make it, we've not going to live 400 light years. We're not gonna—" Course you could take a shortcut through a wormhole, couldn't you?
What's that?
Oh, nooo, NOO, NOOOO!
Ricky laughs
Let's not talk about the universe, please. Let's talk about something you could comprehend, Karl.
Well, listen...
Were you on Richard and Judy yesterday?
Yeah.
Tell us about that.
It was good, it was good fun.
Yeah?
It's a bit surreal.
Is it?
Yeah, it's nice though. I really— there's something charming about them...
Mm, mmm.
...d'you know what I mean? They go off on tangents, they sort of digress,
They suddenly think of something, she'll suddenly go "ooh, my jumper's itching" or somat, you know...
Yeah.
...and it's quite charming, it's not annoying at all.
Yeah.
And I'd never seen them do it through before and— I hope I didn't insult them because I said it was like an adult Blue Peter.
Right. In what way?
Well they had a Christmas wrapping competition, then they had a...
They had a what, a Christmas wrapping competition?
Yeah, and then they had—
That wasn't them doing hip hop?
Then they had what the French people are like, there was a little— didn't quite understand that, living in France. Then they had a
Woman who relived an Elizabethan Christmas.
Steve laughs
The bit that made me laugh was she was announcing this through an Elizabethan microphone and PA...
Steve laughs
...to all the people sitting around dressed as...
I'm a bit confused, this sounds fascinating.
It was good, though. And at the end I said "next week I'll be washing the tortoise" and that, and the producer said "if you do want to make something for the show, we'll definitely feature it".
Ha!
So I might make some of those things they used to make on Blue Peter, like sending—
You know, I remember they made a chest of drawers out of three match boxes.
Yeah, y-y-yeah.
For Barbie dolls or somat, or Action Man.
I seem to remember them showing you how to make a Dusty Bin once.
What, on Blue Peter?
Yeah. I made one, I remember making one.
Really?
Yeah.
I haven't— see I haven't watched Blue Peter obviously for, like, 25 years...
Yeah.
...but is it the same sort of thing?
I think it's pretty much the same now, yeah. Occasionally they'll have kind of— larger dramatic scenes that all the cast will kind of act out, murder mysteries and stuff like that.
Oh, yeah.
It's a bit more of that going on.
Do they still have the
Kodo drummers from Japan over?
I think the kodos come on like twice a week.
With the shiniest buttocks I've ever seen.
Yeah.

Greased- they're in like- sort of nappies or whatever they call them, and they're playing the drums, and you seem them from behind playing these big drums and they've got shiny buttocks. The lights really pick up their- their arses.
I think they've- because they've kind of funked it up since we were younger. Because I remember it was always stuff like, "Let's have a look at this traction engine".
Yeah.
Drive some traction engines. One, very small. One slightly larger one and then you needed a larger one.
Exactly.
Then we'll just drive them around the studio.
No, cos you're going up Nelson's column with Shep.
Yeah.
You might die, you might not.
But I always wondered if perhaps the people in charge were not- perhaps down with the kids when those are like-
I didn't think they were.
What are we going to do this week? Let's have a look around a traction engine  That's what the kids of the early eighties want.
Exactly. But it was- they did used to sneak in education. Whereas Magpie- that was just like funky people who are sort of really in the seventies.
Never watched Magpie.
No, I know I got it wrong as well. I did used to watch it, but I used to watch Blue Peter. I think I was conned.

I always feared- because I- because see with a Blue Peter, I felt like I was learning something. I imagine on Magpie, it was was just, you know, Mr. T came round and- or whatever. It was a lot more cool.
Yeah, it was a lot more cool. And a lot more throwaway. It was sort of like- Magpie was sort of like Look In on telly.
Right, yeah yeah yeah.
You know. What happened to Look In?
Dunno. Each week in the Junior TV times, I don't know. There's probably people listening who have never even heard of Look In.
Is that what it was?
Apparently so.
But there was cartoons and things.
Yeah. It was just basically an advert for ITV, Look In.
Oh was it?
Almost entirely yeah.
And did it have- did it have like a Laurel and Hardy strip or something?
No, it would have things like 'The Story of Five Star'.
Really? Is it like- is it like the ones in the News of the World?
Not dissimilar.
Brilliant.
Yeah.
"Hey, I've had five kids".
Next picture. "Bought one of them a guitar". Next one, "We're at number 7".
Yeah!
Brilliant. Next week, Tina Turner.
I love the fact that Five Star is still touring. There's only three of them now.
Really?
They're still called Five Star.

Really? Yeah. There was four Boney M's at one point. Tribute acts that each one of them had- and then there was a fifth who was someone who wasn't the original member of one of the Boney M's who set up a splinter group. It was ridiculous.
Yeah.
I don't know how many there are now. I was thinking what we should do on the show as well is have a doctor. To just sit in the corner.
Right. Is this because you're worried about your health?
No, no. Just someone when Karl says "Why are your bollocks there?" The doctor can now go. "Well, let's ask Doctor". And he goes, "They're there because..." And we need a vet as well.
Is Dr. Fox still available?
Ricky laughs
We need, we need the doctor. Probably a vet. Some sort of vet or a naturalist would be good. And what else? Oh and a physicist or something, or an astronomer. What do you think Karl?
I'd love that.
Would you really?
Yeah yeah.
Are there- is there any doctors listening? Of course there- as if a doctor would listen to this.
Steve laughs

If there- if you are a doctor- I want a qualified doctor. I don't mean someone who's in their second year of medical school. We're not interested in that. Right, a qualified doctor, a GP, or any specialist. And you maybe want to contribute regularly. Give us a call.
Yeah.
We'll even give you a special phone line and stuff.
Yeah.
Not for now though, we're going to get a lot of mentalists aren't we?
I would adopt a nom de plume. An alternative, you know, identity. Because your patients are going to flee if they find out you listen to this tripe.
Exactly. What's the phone number Karl?
Well, they might as well just email in with their number, mightn't they?
That's cause you don't like answering the phone.
No, I just think it's a better way of doing it.
Okay. How can they prove they are a doctor?
Just, uh-
Go on Karl?
Somat to do with, uh...
Ricky sniggers
Go on.
Go on.
Something to do with, uh...
What thing could they say, that we'd say "well he's definitely a doctor or he wouldn't know that". Think of somat.
But I'm not a doctor, so...
We're on the radio, Karl! When we ask you a question you've got to speak!

I know, I'm just thinking I don't know how you'd know, because you don't— you never ask him, do you? If you need their help, you don't think of going "now before you do this, do you know what you're doing?"
Ricky laughs
But saying that, right...
Go on. Go on.
Talking about this the other day.
Yeah.
Ohh, what was it now?
Ricky laughs
Listen, the fella, no listen.
Play a record!
This is...
Play a record.
Ricky continues to laugh
Alright.
Alright, no come on he's got it now.
Go on, go on.
This fella...
Yeah.
...goes to the doctors.
Yeah...

Ohh right, OK. Right, if this is in any way apocryphal, stupid, illogical, impossible, right? You are never ever speaking again on radio. So make sure this is at least possible. I'll tell you what, I'll even give you improbable but possible, so for anything that breaks the laws of the universe or logic, OK, that's all you have to avoid. On you go.
Right. So this fella, right, he goes to the doctors cause he's got earache.
Right, OK if a chimp's
Living in his brain...
Steve chuckles
...that he gives...
Go on!
Go on.

So he's got earache, he's sat in the waiting room and it's all— his ear's all bunged up and it's hurting a lot and what have you. So the doctor comes out and he goes [muffled noises]. Right? And because his ear's all bunged up, he doesn't hear it that well, right. So he thinks, "it must have been me", right, so he wanders in...
Ricky slumps in his chair and hits the desk
Keep going, keep going, keep going.
Anyway, he...
[partially off-mic] I tell you, I'm gonna hate this. I can just feel it in my bones. Steve, I'm going to let you take over. OK.
Go on, let's hear it. Come on.
OK.
So the doctor says "sit yourself down there"
Right, so he sits himself down. He goes "right, take your pants off". Right?
Ricky sniggers
So he's thinking, "that's a bit odd". Anyway, he uh...
He heard that though.
He, apparently he took his tackle off. The doctor like, did some operation.
What, there in the waiting room?!
Steve laughs
No, in his office.
In his office, yeah.
What?
Erm...
Right, right, so he removed what, his genitals?
Yeah.
In his office.
What, why, why Karl? Why Karl?
Because, he hadn't called him in.
Oh he'd called in a bloke who wanted his testicles taken off, and he didn't hear it! You f— you yyyeeeeee — uh!
Steve laughs
What?!
It was...

So the doctor went out and said, "Mr. Jones, who's here for me to whip off your cock and balls, just here and now", right, bloke comes in, didn't— "must have been me". So the bloke who wanted his balls taken off didn't say "oh, I think he said me", so he's— so he didn't interrupt then! So the bloke goes in, he starts taking his testicles off...
Karl moans and begins the song
...and he doesn't say "I'm here for me ears"!
Snow Patrol - Run
That's the new single from Snow Patrol, and "Run". That's brilliant, innit?
It's good stuff.
On Xfm, 104.9.
Rick.
Go on.
I'm about to say three little words to you...
Yep.
...that I've never said to anyone before.
Go on.
Karl is right.
On what, though?

From Reuters, someone's emailed in, "a Brazilian man who went to a clinic to have an aching ear checked ended up having a vasectomy after mistakenly believing that the doctor had called his name. He had gone in there, entered the vasectomy room when he was called... he was called by the full name and yet thought it was him. But the strangest thing is that he asked no questions when the doctor started preparations in the area which had so little to do with his ear. He later explained that he thought it was an ear inflammation that have got down to
His testicles", and um, the fellas came off.
Extraordinary.
Alright?
I'm stunned.
Amazing, isn't it?
But there's lots of things that keep coming true with Karl's nonsense. There's a programme on next week— "the boy who gave birth to his twin".
Steve sighs
Oh.
And he's there, he's like pregnant with this thing, you know.
How long ago did we do that?
Ricky sniggers
Yeah, you discussed that years ago.
When I talked about it was a baby who had a baby. Now it's a boy who's like a grown man and that, it's took them ages to sort that out.
Mmm.
I did it in one link one Saturday...
Ha, yeah.
...with the full story.
Right? Keeps happening. We've done like Donal MacIntyre's thing, right, he's been ripping us off. I did Cheap As Chimps...
Yeah.
He's been doing it.
No he hasn't.
He has, he's done some programme about how much it costs to get a monkey and that.
Right.
What else have we done?
[laughing] He believes this.
Yeah, y-y-yeah.
There's loads of stuff we've done like that.
You had the worm— the maggot coming out the head. I laughed at you... yeah. In the program didn't see him wrapping the head in bacon, but I mean the principle's there.
Bob Holness has ripped off Rockbusters.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, and he ripped you off years ago.
Yeah.
He's been ripping you off for years, which is even more annoying.
Yeah.
So uh, yeah.
Interesting.
Uhh, yesterday, you know Richard and Judy gave you the tea picked by monkeys.
Yep.
I told you about that either last week or the week before.
Yeah, and then you also told me that there's a place where they grow coffee where the weasels come out
And eat the coffee, right, but they have too much of it and vomit. And they sell the vomit because it makes the coffee smoother.
Weasel vomit?
Yeah. Absolute shize...
It's not, it's not.
Right...
When you say it like that it sounds ridiculous.
Steve laughs
Yeah.
Whereas the way you'd say it...
Yeah.
No, there's...
Why do they keep taking the coffee? Probably addicted to it.
Cause you get addicted to it, don't you, caffeine and that.
Yeah. Why do they sick it up then, cause they have too much?
Cause they're tired, they can't sleep. They sort of...
Ricky giggles
"They're tired, they can't sleep"...
So they get ill, it eventually wears them down. They're sick, and then they— they sell it.
I showed— there's people send monkey news all the time, for Karl...
Yep.
...and I showed him one earlier which said there's a new monkey hospital that's been opened.
Yep. Karl immediately—
Now that's for the— for the treatment of monkeys, Rick.
But he immediately thought it was run by monkeys in white coats.
Yes.
Did he really?
Yes, and he was disappointed cause it wasn't.
He was assuming there'd be little janitors, is that what you said? Yeah, little janitors mopping up.
Karl!
Little chimps with the ECG machines, whatever they're called.
Ricky makes chimp sounds
Ah-ah-ah, clear!
Yeah, exactly.
Brilliant.
He was almost angry...
Yeah.
...disappointed with it.
And what's this about Donna Air giving her baby to a gorilla for a week?
It happened.
No it didn't happen!
She had a baby, they went on the honeymoon, they left it to a little gorilla to look after.
Ricky burst out laughing
Don't! Talk! Absolute!...
It's— don't talk— ohhh Karl!
Again, there's people online now so they can have a look at Ananova. D'you want to give— d'you want to give some stuff away?
Ricky laughs

He used to get through loads of them. Well, I didn't... I wasn't that bad, but my brother..
Well no, because you... you had things like 'trouble with your marrow and that, now you might die. I'm not interested.'

Yeah, but no matter what he did, do you know what I mean, when he was a bus driver, he was one of them who always had a woman stood at the front with him and sort of, you know, having a chat and stuff.
Sure.
He sort of got kicked out of that and stuff.
When he was a bus driver, did he own the bus? Or did he just take it to get pack of fags?
So he's is in Germany, and the Army people say to him...
Now, we know what you're like, Pilkington. All right?
Das Pilke.
Don't be don't be uh,  don't be meeting up with any German women.
Fraulines, leave the fraulines alone.
Not allowed to go out with German women. Because they... Apparently they get you and then they beat you up and that.
What? The German women?
Why?
Go on.
Dunno, just because they said, they don't like English Army man. English Army people and that.
Why?
See... English is your first language, isn't it?
Are you speaking German now, or?
Oh, I can't tell!
"Don't get out with the Germans... they beat you up and that... don't like English Army man".
What is that?
What worries me Rick is because we've got the face, the body language and things to try and interpret this gobbledygook. The listeners, they've just got the words.
I know, yeah. It must be just ridiculous for a listener.
Right, just do the competition. What was that anecdote about? Don't go out with German women - they'll beat you up?
I'm just saying when if you're in the Army, if you're about to join the Army, and you think it will be great and you'll meet loads of women over in Germany... It's not going to happen.
Wise words there, wise words.
This station's a public service.
Excellent? Okay.
Right. Can we just play a song and then do the film thing?
No! just do the film thing now.
No, let's play a song.
Oh f... what we playing?
Bit of Bragg?
Billy Bragg, excellent.
Yeah.
What's this called?
It's called called The Saturday Boy, Karl.
Billy Bragg - The Saturday Boy
Billy Bragg The Sunday Boy on Xfm 104.9. Ricky's laughing cause he's just thrown something at Karl
It made him jump.
Yeah, that's worked well.
Ricky laughs
Well here's the the prizes for the film quiz thing, which I think is what it's called. Brilliant. People will be loving this - it's Trance Anthems 2003, we got a lot of Trance fans listing.
Brilliant.
The Best Air Guitar, obviously, and of course, there are "The Best Club Anthems", Series 1 of "Happiness" by Paul Whitehouse, "The Very Best of Father Ted" on DVD.
We've got "Teachers", we've got "Knowing Me, Knowing You"... not too bad. The three bundles, good stuff, Christmas gifts and things like that. So...
That "Knowing Me Knowing You" I've noticed is on VHS, which is good. Yeah, that's quite quaint. Excellent. Brilliant.
Alright?
Yeah.
So what's the conceit of this?

It's when, you know, we sort of dig out a film that I've been in, and this is... Don't know if i want to tell you what film is because that might be the question thinking about it. Because there isn't that much going on in the clip.
I think we need to know what the film is.
Do you?
Yeah.
Alright, it's Rain Man.
Okay.
Why is he called Rain Man?
: Is that going to be the question?
Yeah, I know that. I know the answer Karl. Don't worry, don't look at me like that.
No I do I do...
Oh well done - you watched the film, yeah you should.
Right so it's you Karl in the film Rainman.
Yeah it's a bit when Tom Cruise is in the doctors with er... with the f... with the ill man.
Ricky sniggers
Here we go. You ready?
[Karl in the film Rainman]
Well, I'm not a psychiatrist, but I do know that his brain doesn't work like other people's.
Oi! I am sat here. Don't go talking about me like I'm some sort of div kid. I've got a good brain.
It works well, it stores all sorts of information and stuff, don't it, Tom?
Yeah he remembers things, little things, sometimes.
Don't say it like that... little things... as if it's stuff that isn't important.
Are you good with numbers?
The doctors asking your question.

Yeah I know, I'm just thinking... good with numbers... It depends, not that good at maths. But I remember facts that have got numbers in them. Like I know that one person in two billion will live to be a hundred and sixteen or over. Alright? Weird thing is a lot of them are Chinese so, you know, makes you wonder... if they're lying...
I'm afraid I don't understand what you're talking about.
What do you mean you don't understand?
It's not... all right, here's an easy one for you then. Goldfish have better memories than people think.
He's right.
He's right?
Yeah.
See? There you go.
Uhh goldfish related - oldest goldfihsh in the world was 41.
No.
Yeah, funny thing is there is if it was a goldfish with a dodgy memory, it could have been older. Could have been you know, pushing 45.
That's amazing, I mean that is amazing... you should work for NASA something like that.
Well. I wouldn't go that far. You know, they're the sort of things I like reading about. I've got that big book there, it's full of sort of...
Did you read all of this?
Yeah. Just don't...
You read all these stories that are in this book?
Don't bother touching it.
Maybe you had better put it back.
Give it back! Get off...
Okay, take it easy. I'm not gonna... I won't touch anything else.
Look at that.
Can I ask you something else Raymond?
No.  You've annoyed me now. You can't come in here, saying I'm daft and that. Messing with me book. Just go, will you?
Were they messing with your big book of freaky facts? Yeah... that's out of order.
Good. So what's the question? Why is he called Rain Man?
Yeah?
Yeah?
Everyone happy with that question?
Yeah?
Yeah.
Okay Ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk - why is he called rainman?
Alright?
Yep.
*whoooosh XFM*

metadata.song_album: And I Feel Fine.....The Best Of The IRS Years 82-87 Collector's Edition

transcript.content: Bad Day - REM
Bad Day, REM, XFM 104.9. That's nearly it, innit? Got through another one. Got through another one, seamlessly.
That we had just moments ago, it was Karl featured in "Rain Man". The question was, why is he and the film called Rain Man? The answer, Ricky, was...?
Well, Tom Cruise's character when he was little couldn't say Raymond and used to call him Rain Man.
OK. Plenty of right answers, but we're going to give it to John Steele who interestingly is from West Yorkshire. He's listening...
Yeah.
...up there. So they're everywhere
That is interesting!
Ha, it is. It is.
Yeah.
So that's pretty much that, is there time for Monkey News?
I think we've gotta have Monkey News...
Let's play the...
...and then that second track from the Ryan Adams album.
Let's play the jingle though, if we can.
Oooh, chimpanzee that! Monkey News ya ffff—
Right. Now uhhh, it was back in the 1980s.
Right. So it is quite topical then.
Mmm.
When did this happen then, 1980s?
Yeah.
Yep.
It's about a Colombian F1 sort of— Formula One driver.
Yep.
Ricky loudly sighs
Apparently these races were going on, right, and uh... someone kept winning them.
Steve bursts out laughing
Ohh right OK, forget it. Forget it.
No don't do it. Cause it's rubbish!
Right, so someone kept winning the races.
So this someone— this human, that kept winning the races. So this human being that kept winning the races, Karl, what was his name?
His name is here, it's Jimmy something.
Yeah? How tall was he? Just out of interest.
Well no, no...
No, no, no, how tall was he?
No let's hear the story, let's hear the story.
Was he about 4'8?
...let me tell the story, you might find out if I tell you the story.
Yep.
Alright?
Go on.
So anyway, he kept winning and everyone was like "oh he's brilliant this guy, who is he?" and all that.
Yeah.
But his gimmick, right...
Was never showing his body or face?
That's right, that's right...
You're joking!
...never took his helmet off.
You are— you're an idiot.
Never took his helmet off, right?
You know the short trousers he used to wear, you know his trousers were about a foot long, but his shirts, the sleeves were really long!
Anyway right, so because he wouldn't take his helmet off...
You're an idiot!
...and he was taking part in like the F3...
[impatiently] Yep.
...which is the lower ranks of Formula One and that.
Just get to it. Just get to...
Everyone thought it was a famous driver who was taking part in...
Just get to it
Being a monkey. Then you can go home.
Anyway what happened was, there was a crash one day.
Yep.
And the car tips over, everyone's like "ohhh"...
He ran up a tree?
Steve giggles
He ran away from the ambulance people up a tree and started eating a banana?
So the marshals ran over and the ambulance people were there, and they were about to take his helmet off, and the marshal was like "don't take his helmet off!"
It'd give away the secret that he's a monkey?
It'd give away the secret and that.
Yeah, chimp?
Took his helmet off...
Jimmy Chimp— Jimmy Chimpus?
...little monkey under there.
No. Definitely not. OK, let's play Ryan Adams...
Did he survive?
Let me just— couple of questions, did he survive?
Yeah he did, yeah. He was allowed to keep all the awards that he won, but he wasn't allowed to take part in any other races.
Yep. Didn't happen, this is Ryan Adams. We'll see you next week.
Yeah this is a song called "The Shadowlands" also from that "Life Is Hell" album. It's good stuff.
Steve giggles
Idiot!
Ryan Adams - Shadowlands

synopsis.description: German man teaches his dog to do the Nazi salute.
Karl thinks the German accent is fine with blokes but not with women.
